unnormalised: ## The Curious Case of the Area Under the Curve: My Brush with Integral Calculus
normalised: ## The Curious Case of the Area Under the Curve: My Brush with Integral Calculus

unnormalised: It all started, like most things in my life, with chai. Not the chai itself, but the rings it left on my desk. See, I’m a coder, not a mathematician. But my roommate, Rohan, he's proper maths obsessed. One evening, I had this perfect, albeit messy, chai stain - a beautiful, irregular blob. Rohan saw it and got this gleam in his eye.
normalised: It all started, like most things in my life, with chai. Not the chai itself, but the rings it left on my desk. See, I’m a coder, not a mathematician. But my roommate, Rohan, he's proper maths obsessed. One evening, I had this perfect, albeit messy, chai stain - a beautiful, irregular blob. Rohan saw it and got this gleam in his eye.

unnormalised: “Aha!” he exclaimed, pointing at the stain. “Tell me, what's the exact area of *that*?”
normalised: “Aha!” he exclaimed, pointing at the stain. “Tell me, what's the exact area of *that*?”

unnormalised: I scoffed. "Rohan, I can tell you the hex code for that shade of brown, but the area? Good luck!"
normalised: I scoffed. "Rohan, I can tell you the hex code for that shade of brown, but the area? Good luck!"

unnormalised: He just smiled that infuriatingly knowing smile of his. "Integral calculus, my friend. It's all about finding the area under a curve. Even a chai-stained one!" He started scribbling on a napkin, muttering something about limits and infinitesimals. Honestly, it sounded like he was summoning a demon, not solving a problem.
normalised: He just smiled that infuriatingly knowing smile of his. "Integral calculus, my friend. It's all about finding the area under a curve. Even a chai-stained one!" He started scribbling on a napkin, muttering something about limits and infinitesimals. Honestly, it sounded like he was summoning a demon, not solving a problem.

unnormalised: My initial reaction was to roll my eyes. I mean, I remembered vaguely learning about integrals in class 12, maybe… barely. The teacher, Mrs. Sharma, always went on about antiderivatives and the fundamental theorem of calculus. All I remembered was the ∫ symbol looking like a stretched-out 'S' and a lot of confusing notation. But Rohan's enthusiasm was infectious, and I was, admittedly, a little intrigued.
normalised: My initial reaction was to roll my eyes. I mean, I remembered vaguely learning about integrals in class twelve, maybe… barely. The teacher, missus Sharma, always went on about antiderivatives and the fundamental theorem of calculus. All I remembered was the integral symbol looking like a stretched-out 'S' and a lot of confusing notation. But Rohan's enthusiasm was infectious, and I was, admittedly, a little intrigued.

unnormalised: He explained that the integral, written as ∫f(x) dx from a to b, basically chopped up the area under the curve into infinitely thin rectangles. Each rectangle had a tiny width, dx, and a height determined by the function f(x). Adding up the areas of all those tiny rectangles gave you the total area under the curve *between* the points a and b.
normalised: He explained that the integral, written as integral of f of x d x from a to b, basically chopped up the area under the curve into infinitely thin rectangles. Each rectangle had a tiny width, d x, and a height determined by the function f of x. Adding up the areas of all those tiny rectangles gave you the total area under the curve *between* the points a and b.

unnormalised: "Think of it like this," he said, grabbing another napkin (much to my horror). "Imagine you're calculating the total rainfall in Mumbai during the monsoon. You have the rainfall rate (mm/hour) as a function of time. Integrating that function over the entire monsoon season gives you the total rainfall in mm." He scrawled something that looked like ∫ rainfall(t) dt from june 1 to sept 30.
normalised: "Think of it like this," he said, grabbing another napkin (much to my horror). "Imagine you're calculating the total rainfall in Mumbai during the monsoon. You have the rainfall rate (millimeter per hour) as a function of time. Integrating that function over the entire monsoon season gives you the total rainfall in millimeter." He scrawled something that looked like integral of rainfall of t d t from june one to september thirty.

unnormalised: Suddenly, it started to click. It wasn’t just about abstract functions anymore. It was about real-world stuff! Rohan then showed me how to calculate the area under a simple curve like f(x) = x^2 between x = 0 and x = 2. Turns out, it involves finding the antiderivative (which is x^3/3 in this case), plugging in the limits, and subtracting. The answer, 8/3, wasn't nearly as intimidating as the process seemed initially.
normalised: Suddenly, it started to click. It wasn’t just about abstract functions anymore. It was about real-world stuff! Rohan then showed me how to calculate the area under a simple curve like f of x equals x squared between x equals zero and x equals two. Turns out, it involves finding the antiderivative (which is x cubed divided by three in this case), plugging in the limits, and subtracting. The answer, eight divided by three, wasn't nearly as intimidating as the process seemed initially.

unnormalised: He then presented me with another challenge, finding the area under f(x) = sin(x) between 0 and π. This one required a little more thought, as the antiderivative of sin(x) is -cos(x). After a bit of head-scratching and a few nervous glances at Rohan's smug face, I managed to arrive at the correct answer: 2.
normalised: He then presented me with another challenge, finding the area under f of x equals sine of x between zero and pi. This one required a little more thought, as the antiderivative of sine of x is negative cosine of x. After a bit of head-scratching and a few nervous glances at Rohan's smug face, I managed to arrive at the correct answer: two.

unnormalised: It wasn't just about getting the right answers, though. It was about understanding the *why*. Why does this method work? Why does finding the antiderivative lead to the area? Rohan patiently explained the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, which connects differentiation and integration. It was like unlocking a secret code, seeing the underlying order in what seemed like chaotic mess.

unnormalised: Now, I'm not saying I'm ready to tackle triple integrals or anything. But I've definitely developed a newfound appreciation for integral calculus. I even started seeing integrals in everyday life – the distance traveled by my auto-rickshaw as the integral of its speed over time, the total electricity consumption in my apartment as the integral of the power drawn over a month. Maybe Mrs. Sharma was right all along. Calculus *is* useful! And maybe, just maybe, one day I'll be able to accurately calculate the area of that chai stain.
